body.name: The 6:20 Man: A Thriller
body.description: A cryptic murder pulls a former soldier turned financial analyst deep into the corruption and menace that prowl beneath the opulent world of finance, in #1 New York Times bestselling author David Baldacci’s new thriller.Every day without fail, Travis Devine puts on a cheap suit, grabs his faux-leather briefcase, and boards the 6:20 commuter train to Manhattan, where he works as an entry-level analyst at the city’s most prestigious investment firm. In the mornings, he gazes out the train window at the lavish homes of the uberwealthy, dreaming about joining their ranks. In the evenings, he listens to the fiscal news on his phone, already preparing for the next grueling day in the cutthroat realm of finance. Then one morning Devine’s tedious routine is shattered by an anonymous email: She is dead. Sara Ewes, Devine’s coworker and former girlfriend, has been found hanging in a storage room of his office building—presumably a suicide, at least for now—prompting the NYPD to come calling on him. If that wasn’t enough, before the day is out, Devine receives another ominous visit, a confrontation that threatens to dredge up grim secrets from his past in the army unless he participates in a clandestine investigation into his firm. This treacherous role will take him from the impossibly glittering lives he once saw only through a train window, to the darkest corners of the country’s economic halls of power . . . where something rotten lurks. And apart from this high-stakes conspiracy, there’s a killer out there with their own agenda, and Devine is the bull’s-eye. Read more

productInformation.name: Narrator
productInformation.value: Zachary Webber, Christine Lakin, Mela Lee

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Intriguing and Engrossing Spy Thriller and Murder Mystery
reviews.reviewText: This book had a slow start for me as it introduced the characters and set the stage for the action, but once it got going, it took off like a rocket. Devine is a former marine who currently works at an investment house in NYC when he is tapped to do some spying by someone who knows about his past and can do irreparable damage. Thus, he is dragged into investigating crimes and murder. The pace was good, the characters were believable and the surprise twists were a welcome breath of fresh air. I enjoyed the read and look forward to the next book in the series. Now I am hooked on the character and the intrigue!DisclaimerI own a copy of this book and was not required to write a positive review. All opinions expressed are my own.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Fun read, but -- I have a few questions...
reviews.reviewText: Baldacci's "The 6:20 Man" was a fun read, but in my view there are a couple basic flaws in the plotline that make me reluctant to invest time and money in the sequel.o What, exactly, was she signaling by wearing a red or green bikini every few days as Our Hero watched from the 6:20 train? What critical secret message could be conveyed at a data rate of about 1 bit per day? I know this is picky, but the beautiful-girl-seen-from-the-train trope is really central to the story, and it ultimately doesn't seem to make any sense.o At the beginning of this book's sequel, we see Our Hero take out a trio of armed baddies because he intuited they were out to get him, based only their body language. How could he so blind not to recognize the psychotic villain in this story?o What happened to the Fiendish Diabolical Conspiracy Behind It All? The blurb for the sequel says Our Hero took down the "world’s largest financial conspiracy," but, he didn't. If the FDCBIA is coming back in a sequel, it would have been fun to end this book with, e.g., a mysterious conversation between two shadowy characters, brushing off their temporary setback. "And this Devine guy, what of him?" -- "He's being dealt with."

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book held my interest and I was always second guessing the outcome. I loved the main character as well as the plot. I plan to buy the next book in the series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I didn’t know what to expect when I began this book. It was a real page turner from about one quarter of the book on. Travis, an ex army ranger, is now working at a financial institution, trying to rise up in a world he doesn’t really love, he is recruited by Mr. Campbell, a man he can’t refuse. He had done something in the army that led to his retirement. There is murder and financial manipulations for him to try to sort out. It is well written and very exciting to read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2024
reviews.reviewText: The plot summary near the end of the read sort of made the prior hours of reading seem an exercise. I’m neutral on the book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not bad for a debut series.
reviews.reviewText: It is definitely a different direction to the previous series, a Memory Man. I am a big fan of that series. I hope Mr Baldacci will not retire that series.This debut series is not too bad. I like the idea of the combination of high finance and military. I don’t think there are many books around base on this background. The book started off very well until about a third quarter of the book where it became quite slow then, the pace pick up. The ending was unexpected. As the saying goes, the person one least expected is one person who becomes your worst enemy. Overall a good book indeed. Highly recommend the book to those readers who love a good twist at the end.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars captivating with a great twisted end.
reviews.reviewText: I like the authors style of writing. When a book allows my mind to visualize the story, then I know it’s a great read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Though I am a Mid not a Westie, I appreciated the sense of duty and honor possessed by Travis Devine. He is definitely one of us!! The book moved fast and kept my attention. It was a fun ride.
Another good Baldacci book. Like most of his books.
A good characters and the right amout of information about the facts. It was a good reading and I hope we could see more of that..
As always, Baldacci takes you on a roller.coaster of w beho is really who. \When you finally figure who the bad guys are, turns out they are not.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Thrilling read with a very unexpected twist at the end.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just the way i like it.
reviews.reviewText: Multiple characters well described, a story all but straight, a hero with too much luck, but more or less human skills.
